metadata.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Ganeswara Rao & Lakshminarayana Rao

facts.text: Andhra Engineering Co. (AECO) originally a partnership firm formed by D.L.N. Raju in 1929 converted into private limited company with headquarters at Visakhapatnam.
AECO obtained licences under Electricity Act for supply of electrical energy to Visakhapatnam, Anakapalli and other places.
In 1933, Raju floated Visakhapatnam Electric Supply Corporation Ltd. (VESCO), public limited company; AECO transferred Visakhapatnam licence to VESCO.
In 1936, Anakapalli Electric Supply Corporation Ltd. floated; AECO appointed Managing Agent for VESCO and others under agreements.
Managing agency agreement with VESCO for 15 years from 1933 to 1948, renewed till licence term; VESCO undertaking acquired by Government in June 1952.
D.L.N. Raju died in 1939; succeeded by R.K.N.G. Raju as Managing Director of AECO, who stayed mostly at Rajahmundry.
In 1939, D.V. Appala Raju appointed as AECO representative and Secretary of VESCO; resigned in 1944.
Respondent No.1 Ganeswara Rao, old AECO employee since 1923 as stenotypist, became Head Clerk, then appointed Secretary of VESCO and resident representative of Managing Agents.
Respondent No.1 attended to day-to-day affairs of VESCO including receiving money, spending, staff control, purchases, accounts.
Till 1945, C.P. Rao & Co. auditors of VESCO; after Respondent No.1 became Secretary, B. Rajan elected auditor for VESCO and other concerns.
R.K.N.G. Raju died in April 1948.

Conspiracy hatched in 1947 by Respondent No.1 with approver K.V. Ramana, Respondent No.2 Lakshminarayana Rao, K.S.N. Murty and others to misappropriate VESCO funds till end of managing agency in 1948 (renewed till 1952).
Approver K.V. Ramana promoted from Accounts Clerk to Senior Accountant; others shuffled positions.
After R.K.N.G. Raju death, AECO indebted to concerns; VESCO shown indebted to Andhra Cement Rs.42,000 paid by AECO from VESCO funds.
G.V. Subba Raju (PW 25) appointed Managing Director of AECO mid-1948, assured minimal duties, Respondent No.1 to handle affairs.
VESCO received cheques from high tension consumers, cash from domestic via bill collectors to Respondent No.2.
Respondent No.2 maintained private notebook for payments on slips by Respondent No.1, entered as 'by safe' in Handover Book though not.
Respondent No.1 opened personal accounts in banks; Respondent No.2 sent equivalent cash for cheques.
Ledger heading 'advance purchase of materials' for misappropriated amounts without orders.
Subba Raju visited twice monthly, explained shortages as sent to bank.
C.S. Raju appointed to supervise VESCO; new 'suspense account' started, Rs.1 lakh passed through.
New cash book prepared to cover misappropriations.
Subbaramayya replaced C.S. Raju end 1951 as supervisor; called for info from Respondent No.1, unsatisfied.
S.G. Krishna Aiyar appointed January 1952 for investigation.
General Body meeting Nov 29, 1951 uproar over auditors report; postponed to Dec 9, 1951; produced Ex.P.234 alleged forged.
Krishna Aiyar interim report: Rs.33,271-10-0 to Andhra Power System not paid 1948-49; shortage Rs.90,000.
Respondent No.1 letter Feb 12, 1952 admitted responsibility, agreed to make good shortages.
Further report: Rs.2,38,000 to Andhra Power System not paid; Collector attached properties April 1952.
Respondent No.1 paid Rs.50,000 April 30, 1952 to Andhra Power System, promised balance.
Police complaint by K.S. Dutt May 19, 1952; investigation found misappropriation Rs.3,40,000.
Chargesheet May 13, 1954 against respondents, Murty, Ramana.
Ramana confessed Nov 15, 1954; pardon granted Nov 17, 1954.
Additional Sessions Judge, Visakhapatnam convicted Respondent No.1 on all charges (120B, 409, 477A, 471/467), Respondent No.2 on 120B and 409 r/w 109.
High Court allowed appeals, acquitted respondents, dismissed State revision for enhancement; judgment Jan 30, 1960.
State appealed to Supreme Court by special leave under Art. 136.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was misjoinder of charges and parties under CrPC ss. 233-239, as joint trial for conspiracy, 409, 477A, 471/467 impermissible.
Whether provisions of various clauses of s.239 CrPC can be applied cumulatively.
Whether conspiracy charge valid when offences committed in pursuance thereof.
Validity of pardon to approver Ramana and admissibility/reliability of his evidence.
Whether examination under s.342 CrPC unfair.
Admissibility of account books of other firms to show absence of entries for alleged payments.

petitioner_arguments.text: No misjoinder; s.239 clauses cumulative; offences part of same transaction via conspiracy.
Conspiracy charge valid even after offences committed; usual to charge both.
Pardon to approver legal; evidence reliable, refreshed properly.
S.342 examination adequate; no duty to inform of s.342(4).

respondent_arguments.text: Misjoinder of charges/persons; s.239 clauses mutually exclusive, subject to s.234 limits.
No conspiracy charge after fruits yielded; no personal benefit to Respondent No.2/approver.
S.342 unfair: long questions, documents not provided, cross-examination like, no info on giving evidence.
Account books of others inadmissible to prove non-payment (absence of entries).

court_reasoning.text: S.239 clauses not mutually exclusive; 'and' allows cumulative application; enables joint trial to avoid multiplicity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions of ss.233-236 apply 'so far as may be' to s.239 charges.

court_reasoning.text: Offences connected via conspiracy form same transaction; joint trial valid under s.239(a),(c),(d).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No prejudice shown despite no early objection; s.537 CrPC.

court_reasoning.text: Conspiracy independent offence; chargeable even after substantive offences committed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Usual to charge both conspiracy and offences in pursuance.

court_reasoning.text: Pardon procedure followed; evidence admissible; reliability for High Court on remand.
S.342 questions elaborate but answered; no cross-exam; no duty to inform s.342(4).
Absence of entries relevant under s.11 Evidence Act as inconsistent with fact in issue (payments made).
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.34 makes entries relevant but not sufficient alone; non-existence via s.11.

holdings.text: No misjoinder of charges or parties; s.239 permits cumulative clauses for joint trial.
Account books admissible under s.11 Evidence Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Held s.239 clauses mutually exclusive; disagreed by SC.
Strict construction of exceptions to s.233.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Kandimalla Subbaiah
precedents_cited.relevance: Joint trial under s.239 for multiple offences in same transaction; s.234 limit inapplicable.

precedents_cited.case_name: K.V. Krishna Murthy Iyer v. State of Madras
Willie (William) Slaney v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: S.537 covers charge errors unless failure of justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Birichh Bhuian v. State of Bihar

precedents_cited.relevance: Joint trial for conspiracy and cheating offences.

precedents_cited.case_name: Natwarlal Sakarlal Mody v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Conspiracy impacts ss.235,239 for joint trial.

precedents_cited.case_name: Queen Empress v. Girish Chunder Banerjee
precedents_cited.relevance: Absence of entries not proved by books.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences charged: conspiracy, criminal breach of trust, falsification of accounts, forgery.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Joinder of charges, trial procedure, examination of accused, pardon, revision.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Entries in books relevant but not sufficient; facts inconsistent relevant; refreshing memory.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside High Court acquittal on procedural grounds, held no misjoinder, valid charges, proper procedure; remanded to High Court for fresh decision on merits after considering evidence including approver's.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand to High Court for rehearing appeal on evidence.

key_quotes.text: "The object of enacting s. 239 was to avoid multiplicity of trials and the only limitation which could properly be placed on the trial of several persons for the same kind of or different offences would be that which considerations of justice and fairness would require."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on s.239 CrPC purpose and scope.

key_quotes.text: "Criminal conspiracy as defined in s. 120-A consists of an agreement to do an illegal act or an agreement to do an act which is not illegal by illegal means."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines independent nature of conspiracy offence.

key_quotes.text: "Even if we were to assume that there has been a misjoinder of charges in violation of the provisions of ss. 233 to 239 of the Code, the High Court was incompetent to set aside the conviction of the respondents without coming to the definite conclusion that misjoinder had occasioned failure of justice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
